In the Hesiodic Catalogue of Women, Graecus is presented as the son of Zeus and Pandora II, sister of Hellen the patriarch of Hellenes. Hellen was the son of Deucalion who ruled around Phthia in central Greece. The Parian Chronicle mentions that when Deucalion became king of Phthia, the previously called Graikoi were named Hellenes. Aristotle notes that the Hellenes were related with Grai/Greeks (Meteorologica I.xiv) a native name of a Dorian tribe in Epirus which was used by the Illyrians. He also claims that the great deluge must have occurred in the region around Dodona, where the Selloi dwelt. However, according to the Greek tradition it is more possible that the homeland of the Greeks was originally in central Greece. A modern theory derives the name Greek (Latin Graeci) from Graikos, "inhabitant of Graia/Graea," a town on the coast of Boeotia. Greek colonists from Graia helped to found Cumae (900 BC) in Italy,

In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development of a biological cell or an organelle of a biological organism. Energy is thus often said to be stored by cells in the structures of molecules of substances such as carbohydrates (including sugars), lipids, and proteins, which release energy when reacted with oxygen in respiration. In human terms, the human equivalent (H-e) (Human energy conversion) indicates, for a given amount of energy expenditure, the relative quantity of energy needed for human metabolism, assuming an average human energy expenditure of 12,500 kJ per day and a basal metabolic rate of 80 watts. For example, if our bodies run (on average) at 80 watts, then a light bulb running at 100 watts is running at 1.25 human equivalents (100 ÷ 80) i.e. 1.25 H-e. From 1877 to 1878, the area suffered a rash of stagecoach robberies. Most notable, however, were the two holdups committed by masked road-agent William Whitney Brazelton. Brazelton held up two stages in the summer of 1878 near Point of Mountain Station approximately 17 mi (27 km) northwest of Tucson. John Clum, of Tombstone, Arizona fame was one of the passengers. Brazelton was eventually tracked down and killed on Monday August 19, 1878, in a mesquite bosque along the Santa Cruz River 3 miles (5 km) south of Tucson by Pima County Sheriff Charles A. Shibell and his citizen's posse. Brazelton had been suspected of highway robbery not only in the Tucson area, but also in the Prescott region and Silver City, New Mexico area as well. Brazelton's crimes prompted John J. Valentine, Sr. of Wells, Fargo & Co. to send special agent and future Pima County sheriff Bob Paul to investigate. In 633 AD, Rashidun Arabs invaded Iran and conquered it by 651 AD, largely converting Iranian people from their indigenous faiths of Manichaeism and Zoroastrianism to Sunni Islam. Arabic replaced Persian as the official language, while Persian remained the language of both ordinary people and of literature. Iran became a major contributor to the Islamic Golden Age, producing many influential scientists, scholars, artists, and thinkers. Establishment of the Safavid Dynasty in 1501, converted the Iranian people from Sunni Islam to Twelver Shia Islam, and made Twelver Shia Islam the official religion of Iran. Safavid conversion of Iran from Sunnism to Shiism marked one of the most important turning points in Iranian and Muslim history. Carolingian art was produced for a small group of figures around the court, and the monasteries and churches they supported. It was dominated by efforts to regain the dignity and classicism of imperial Roman and Byzantine art, but was also influenced by the Insular art of the British Isles. Insular art integrated the energy of Irish Celtic and Anglo-Saxon Germanic styles of ornament with Mediterranean forms such as the book, and established many characteristics of art for the rest of the medieval period. Surviving religious works from the Early Middle Ages are mostly illuminated manuscripts and carved ivories, originally made for metalwork that has since been melted down. Objects in precious metals were the most prestigious form of art, but almost all are lost except for a few crosses such as the Cross of Lothair, several reliquaries, and finds such as the Anglo-Saxon burial at Sutton Hoo and the hoards of Gourdon from Merovingian France, Guarrazar from

The brief peace in Europe allowed Napoleon to focus on the French colonies abroad. Saint-Domingue had managed to acquire a high level of political autonomy during the Revolutionary Wars, with Toussaint Louverture installing himself as de facto dictator by 1801. Napoleon saw his chance to recuperate the formerly wealthy colony when he signed the Treaty of Amiens. During the Revolution, the National Convention voted to abolish slavery in February 1794. Under the terms of Amiens, however, Napoleon agreed to appease British demands by not abolishing slavery in any colonies where the 1794 decree had never been implemented. The resulting Law of 20 May never applied to colonies like Guadeloupe or Guyane, even though rogue generals and other officials used the pretext of peace as an opportunity to reinstate slavery in some of these places. The Law of 20 May officially restored the slave trade to the Caribbean colonies, not slavery itself. The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry. The Eclogues, Georgics, and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula with which all educated Romans were familiar. Poets following Virgil often refer intertextually to his works to generate meaning in their own poetry. The Augustan poet Ovid parodies the opening lines of the Aeneid in Amores 1.1.1–2, and his summary of the Aeneas story in Book 14 of the Metamorphoses, the so-called "mini-Aeneid", has been viewed as a particularly important example of post-Virgilian response to the epic genre. Lucan's epic, the Bellum Civile has been considered an anti-Virgilian epic, disposing with the divine mechanism, treating historical events, and diverging drastically from Virgilian epic practice. By the early 18th century, the Maratha Kingdom had transformed itself into the Maratha Empire under the rule of the Peshwas (prime ministers). In 1737, the Marathas defeated a Mughal army in their capital, Delhi itself in Battle of Delhi (1737). The Marathas continued their military campaigns against Mughals, Nizam, Nawab of Bengal and Durrani Empire to further extend their boundaries. Gordon explained how the Maratha systematically took control over new regions. They would start with annual raids, followed by collecting ransom from villages and towns while the declining Mughal Empire retained nominal control and finally taking over the region. He explained it with the example of Malwa region. Marathas built an efficient system of public administration known for its attention to detail. It succeeded in raising revenue in districts that recovered from years of raids, up to levels previously enjoyed by the Mughals. Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859. At that time, Serb and Croat lands were still part of the Ottoman and Austrian Empires. Officially, the language was called variously Serbo-Croat, Croato-Serbian, Serbian and Croatian, Croatian and Serbian, Serbian or Croatian, Croatian or Serbian. By 1959, American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space, because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury's first launch. On April 12, 1961, the USSR surprised the world again by launching Yuri Gagarin into a single orbit around the Earth in a craft they called Vostok 1. They dubbed Gagarin the first cosmonaut, roughly translated from Russian and Greek as "sailor of the universe". Although he had the ability to take over manual control of his spacecraft in an emergency by opening an envelope he had in the cabin that contained a code that could be typed into the computer, it was flown in an automatic mode as a precaution; medical science at that time did not know what would happen to a human in the weightlessness of space. The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 (47 sq mi), and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin (the last volcanic eruptions occurred about 7 million years ago). Coastal areas are covered in volcanic rock and warmer and drier than the centre. The highest point of the island is Diana's Peak at 818 m (2,684 ft). In 1996 it became the island's first national park. Much of the island is covered by New Zealand flax, a legacy of former industry, but there are some original trees augmented by plantations, including those of the Millennium Forest project which was established in 2002 to replant part of the lost Great Wood and is now managed by the Saint Helena National Trust. In January 1938, Milt Gabler started recording for his new label, Commodore Records, and to allow for longer continuous performances, he recorded some 12-inch records. Eddie Condon explained: "Gabler realized that a jam session needs room for development." The first two 12-inch recordings did not take advantage of the extra length: "Carnegie Drag" was 3:15; "Carnegie Jump", 2:41. But at the second session, on April 30, the two 12-inch recordings were longer: "Embraceable You" was 4:05; "Serenade to a Shylock", 4:32. Another way around the time limitation was to issue a selection on both sides of a single record. Vaudeville stars Gallagher and Shean recorded "Mr. Gallagher and Mr. Shean", written by Irving and Jack Kaufman, as two sides of a 10-inch 78 in 1922 for Cameo. In this order, the causes of the resultant pattern of cup fragments and water spill is easily attributable in terms of the trajectory of the cup, irregularities in its structure, angle of its impact on the floor, etc. However, applying the same event in reverse, it is difficult to explain why the various pieces of the cup should fly up into the human hand and reassemble precisely into the shape of a cup, or why the water should position itself entirely within the cup. The state seemed at relative calm compared to the rest of the country due to its close ties to the United States until 1841. In 1843 the possibility of war was anticipated by the state government and it began to reinforce the defense lines along the political boundary with Texas. Supplies of weapons were sent to fully equip the military and took steps to improve efficiency at the presidios. Later, the Regimen for the Defenders of the Border were organized by the state which were made up of: light cavalry, four squads of two brigades, and a small force of 14 men and 42 officials at the price of 160,603 pesos per year. During the beginning of the 1840s, private citizens took it upon themselves to stop the commercial caravans of supplies from the United States, but being so far away from the large suppliers in central Mexico the caravan was allowed to continue in March 1844.

John treated the interdict as "the equivalent of a papal declaration of war". He responded by attempting to punish Innocent personally and to drive a wedge between those English clergy that might support him and those allying themselves firmly with the authorities in Rome. John seized the lands of those clergy unwilling to conduct services, as well as those estates linked to Innocent himself; he arrested the illicit concubines that many clerics kept during the period, only releasing them after the payment of fines; he seized the lands of members of the church who had fled England, and he promised protection for those clergy willing to remain loyal to him. In many cases, individual institutions were able to negotiate terms for managing their own properties and keeping the produce of their estates. By 1209 the situation showed no signs of resolution, and Innocent threatened to excommunicate John if he did not acquiesce to Langton's appointment. The Canadian football field is 150 yards (137 m) long and 65 yards (59 m) wide with end zones 20 yards (18 m) deep, and goal lines 110 yards (101 m) apart. At each goal line is a set of 40-foot-high (12 m) goalposts, which consist of two uprights joined by an 18 1⁄2-foot-long (5.6 m) crossbar which is 10 feet (3 m) above the goal line. The goalposts may be H-shaped (both posts fixed in the ground) although in the higher-calibre competitions the tuning-fork design (supported by a single curved post behind the goal line, so that each post starts 10 feet (3 m) above the ground) is preferred. In 1939, the Bureau began compiling a custodial detention list with the names of those who would be taken into custody in the event of war with Axis nations. The majority of the names on the list belonged to Issei community leaders, as the FBI investigation built on an existing Naval Intelligence index that had focused on Japanese Americans in Hawaii and the West Coast, but many German and Italian nationals also found their way onto the secret list. Robert Shivers, head of the Honolulu office, obtained permission from Hoover to start detaining those on the list on December 7, 1941, while bombs were still falling over Pearl Harbor. Mass arrests and searches of homes (in most cases conducted without warrants) began a few hours after the attack, and over the next several weeks more than 5,500 Issei men were taken into FBI custody. Intended torchbearers Choi Seung-kook and Park Won-sun boycotted the event to protest against the Chinese government's crackdown in Tibet. The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has grown in recent times for economic purposes. The number of successful interspecific mammalian hybrids is relatively small, although it has come to be known that there is a significant number of naturally occurring hybrids between forms or regional varieties of a single species.[citation needed] These may form zones of gradation known as clines. Indeed, the distinction between some hitherto distinct species can become clouded once it can be shown that they may not only breed but produce fertile offspring. Some hybrid animals exhibit greater strength and resilience than either parent. This is known as hybrid vigor. The existence of the mule (donkey sire; horse dam) being used widely as a hardy draught animal throughout ancient and modern history is testament to this. A number of novel ideas about religion developed with the Enlightenment, including Deism and talk of atheism. Deism, according to Thomas Paine, is the simple belief in God the Creator, with no reference to the Bible or any other miraculous source. Instead, the Deist relies solely on personal reason to guide his creed, which was eminently agreeable to many thinkers of the time. Atheism was much discussed, but there were few proponents. Wilson and Reill note that, "In fact, very few enlightened intellectuals, even when they were vocal critics of Christianity, were true atheists. Rather, they were critics of orthodox belief, wedded rather to skepticism, deism, vitalism, or perhaps pantheism." Some followed Pierre Bayle and argued that atheists could indeed be moral men. BYU has 21 NCAA varsity teams. Nineteen of these teams played mainly in the Mountain West Conference from its inception in 1999 until the school left that conference in 2011. Prior to that time BYU teams competed in the Western Athletic Conference. All teams are named the "Cougars", and Cosmo the Cougar has been the school's mascot since 1953. The school's fight song is the Cougar Fight Song. Because many of its players serve on full-time missions for two years (men when they're 18, women when 19), BYU athletes are often older on average than other schools' players. The NCAA allows students to serve missions for two years without subtracting that time from their eligibility period. Of major Canadian cities, St. John's is the foggiest (124 days), windiest (24.3 km/h (15.1 mph) average speed), and cloudiest (1,497 hours of sunshine). St. John's experiences milder temperatures during the winter season in comparison to other Canadian cities, and has the mildest winter for any Canadian city outside of British Columbia. Precipitation is frequent and often heavy, falling year round. On average, summer is the driest season, with only occasional thunderstorm activity, and the wettest months are from October to January, with December the wettest single month, with nearly 165 millimetres of precipitation on average. The success of its football team made Notre Dame a household name. The success of Note Dame reflected rising status of Irish Americans and Catholics in the 1920s. Catholics rallied up around the team and listen to the games on the radio, especially when it knocked off the schools that symbolized the Protestant establishment in America — Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and Army. Yet this role as high-profile flagship institution of Catholicism made it an easy target of anti-Catholicism. The most remarkable episode of violence was the clash between Notre Dame students and the Ku Klux Klan in 1924. Nativism and anti-Catholicism, especially when directed towards immigrants, were cornerstones of the KKK's rhetoric, and Notre Dame was seen as a symbol of the threat posed by the Catholic Church. Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N, and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas: the Swiss Alps to the south, the Swiss Plateau or Central Plateau, and the Jura mountains on the west. The Alps are a high mountain range running across the central-south of the country, comprising about 60% of the country's total area. The majority of the Swiss population live in the Swiss Plateau. Among the high valleys of the Swiss Alps many glaciers are found, totalling an area of 1,063 square kilometres (410 sq mi). From these originate the headwaters of several major rivers, such as the Rhine, Inn, Ticino and Rhône, which flow in the four cardinal directions into the whole of Europe. Boston has a continental climate with some maritime influence, and using the −3 °C (27 °F) coldest month (January) isotherm, the city lies within the transition zone from a humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa) to a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), although the suburbs north and west of the city are significantly colder in winter and solidly fall under the latter categorization; the city lies at the transition between USDA plant hardiness zones 6b (most of the city) and 7a (Downtown, South Boston, and East Boston neighborhoods). Summers are typically warm to hot, rainy, and humid, while winters oscillate between periods of cold rain and snow, with cold temperatures. Spring and fall are usually mild, with varying conditions dependent on wind direction and jet stream positioning. As Muslim institutions of higher learning, the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf. In central and eastern Islamic lands, the view that the madrasa, as a charitable endowment, will remain under the control of the donor (and their descendent), resulted in a "spurt" of establishment of madaris in the 11th and 12th centuries. However, in Western Islamic lands, where the Maliki views prohibited donors from controlling their endowment, madaris were not as popular. Unlike the corporate designation of Western institutions of higher learning, the waqf designation seemed to have led to the exclusion of non-orthodox religious subjects such a philosophy and natural science from the curricula. Compared to other team sports , the National Football League preseason is very structured . Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year , two at home and two away . They start on August 3 rd and end on August 29 th this year . In the preseason , coaches get a sense of what their roster looks like for next season . Many coaches will also experiment with different lineups , formations , plays and schemes to see what works . The teams play as hard as they need to so to not get injured , but not so hard as to cause further more serious injuries . This is the main purpose of the preseason , it is to try and get as many starters back as possible throughout the long season that follows . Teams also sometimes will play second , even third string players so they can get a look at other younger players they have on the roster . It is a chance for these players to be able to gain experience . During these games , some players that have been practicing with the team for some time will finally get their first chance to go on the field .

Intense media interest in the opinions and private lives of the royal family during the 1980s led to a series of sensational stories in the press , not all of them proven . The divorce of the Duchess of York , Sarah Ferguson , and Prince Andrew sparked widespread public interest . The couple were divorced on 30 May 1996 . After a failed 1980s marriage and the recent divorce of Charles , Prince of Wales and Lady Diana Spencer , who gave birth to two sons in 1982 and 1984 , respectively , Prince Andrew. met Camilla Parker Bowles . The marriage between them was to have serious consequences for the future of the monarchy and the popularity of the entire family , and in consequence also for the whole country . The British political leadership reacted sharply . On 6 May 1995 , the press announced the wedding , and the first reports of Camilla 's pregnancy were made . As more and more details of these developments became known , it led to an explosive situation , with newspapers around the world publishing the news . The British government asked the media to stop its reporting , but was unsuccessful , and the entire royal household was confronted with a media storm .

The palace measures 108 metres ( 354 ft ) by 120 metres ( 390 ft ) , is 24 metres ( 79 ft ) high and contains over 77,000 m2 ( 830,000 sq ft ) of floor space . The 600-room palace stands in a central park area known as the Palace of Versailles and was formerly the seat of the French monarchy . Louis XIV chose Versailles as the new official . He and his courtiers built and filled the palace with extravagant furnishings , artwork , and gardens . Louis XIV lived his final years at Versailles , as France struggled with its power , until his death in 1715 . In 1791 , during the French Revolution , the palace was destroyed . It was restored after the revolution but Louis XVI 's daughter , Marie - Antoinette , lived in the palace under the direct protection of the French government . When she was sentenced to death , the palace became the headquarters of France 's National Assembly in 1789 , which created the Constitution of France , and in 1793 , it was completely destroyed . It was not until 1806 , that Napoleon Bonaparte , the current Emperor of the French and a former soldier from a wealthy family , decided to rebuild the palace and return it to its former glory .

Emotions can motivate social interactions and relationships and therefore are directly related with basic physiology , particularly with the stress systems . This is important because emotions are related to brain responses and activity . The relationship between stress and emotions becomes especially relevant when applied to human brain activity and the central nervous system . Emotional experiences are mediated by a group of brain regions , the limbic system , which include the hippocampus and amygdala . The limbic system is responsible for the regulation of mood , the processing of emotional states , and the formation of basic drives . When an individual perceives a situation as a threat , the stress system prepares the body to deal with the danger by mobilizing energy stores and by activating the sympathetic nervous system . This activates the adrenal glands and stimulates the liver to release the hormone cortisol , causing an increase in heart rate . The fight - flight - freeze responses can be the product of a situation that is perceived as either dangerous or unpleasant . The fight - flight - freeze response can involve the central nervous system ( CNS ) as well as the autonomic and endocrine systems during stressful situations that require coping .

Social constructionists believe there is no such thing as an objective reality , as no reality exists other than the one which is constructed by people and their social interactions . Hegel certainly intends to preserve what he takes to be true of German idealism , in particular Kant 's insistence that ethical reason can and does go beyond finite inclinations. Yet Hegel 's view of nature as an autonomous force , on the other hand , seems to contradict Kant , who holds that humans must acknowledge nature as an agent that can and will affect their lives , and take it into consideration . Kant also argues that any individual human has an `` imperfect duty to himself '' to develop his potential and capacities to the limits of his abilities . In Kant , this is primarily the capacity to understand nature . Hence the concept of the natural law , or `` fundamental principle of nature '' , which represents Kant 's notion of the limits of human responsibility . In contrast , Hegel 's notion of freedom is radically different from Kant 's . For Kant , freedom lies in having the choice to do one 's duty according to natural law , an agent 's reason for duty being his own , not a higher being or external law . For Hegel , however , freedom is achieved precisely by having the choice to be the creative power that produces and endows nature .

Knowledge , for Popper , was objective , both in the sense that it is objectively true ( or truthlike ) , and also in the sense that knowledge has an objective source . Popper 's answer to the traditional question `` how do i ( as an individual ) know that such - and - such is the case `` is that he ( or indeed anyone ) knows that such - and - such is the case when he has evidence. This is of course a very unsatisfactory answer and in the next section I shall try very hard to come up with a more satisfactory answer . It is worth taking a moment here , nevertheless , to see just how unacceptable Popper has made his task . In fact , knowledge , for Popper , in any of its senses , depends not only on having a method of learning -- namely , the method of seeking evidence -- but also on having a method of testing the evidence . There is no question , in Popper 's scheme , of what counts as evidence .

The border between Thuringia and Lower Saxony is formed by the Unstrut and Saale rivers , the Elster ( the Saale ) forms the eastern border with Saxony-Anhalt . Saxony is located east of Thuringia and a part of Lower Saxony follows it along the Saale river . Throughout the 14th century , French kings sought to expand their influence at the expense of the territorial holdings of the nobility . They ran into difficulties when attempting to bring royal authority into northern France , however , facing both the local nobility and the growing power of the cities to which many fled to avoid royal domination and which sought to make themselves independent of royal power . As a result , when Joan of Arc emerged as the savior ( or at least leader ) of France , she was the beneficiary of the long struggle to unite the French under the authority of their king . # # Background Joan 's father Jacques d'Arc led a nomadic existence . He had been a tenant on a rented piece of land at Domremy , a tiny village in northeastern Lorraine . D ' Arc , however , lived well beyond his means because his life was centered on the pleasures of hunting and wine . The family lived in poverty while he spent his time and his money in the hunting lodge near the nearby Forest of Vaucouleurs . Following Jacques'death in 1419 , his son and heir , Jean II , moved into the lodge and changed his family status .

The Jurassic Period extends from about 201.3 ± 0.2 to 145.0 Ma . During the early Jurassic , the supercontinent Pangaea broke up into the northern supercontinent Laurasia and the southern supercontinent Gondwana . New ecosystems grew up , including forests , grasslands , and a world-wide coral reef system . By the Middle Jurassic , a vast and largely arid landscape extended over Gondwana , which began experiencing its first great continental drought . By the end of the Middle Jurassic , in the latter part of the Toarcian , the drought ended , but with it the vast Pangaean forest ecosystem of the Jurassic . Ecosystems of the Late Jurassic would resemble modern-day savannas . The Cretaceous Period extends from about 145. 0 to 66. 0 Ma . It began , about 145. 0 Ma , . the Early Cretaceous , . Fossil pollen recovered from rocks in northern Asia reveals that by the Late Jurassic , when dinosaurs appeared , some of those ecosystems may have shifted to arid landscapes where grasslands and small animals flourished . During that time , the Jurassic ecosystem had undergone great changes , leaving a very diverse group of dinosaurs to populate the environment .

The area now called Galicia was first inhabited by humans during the Middle Paleolithic period , and it takes its name from the Gallaeci , the Celtic peoples living north of the river Douro and east of the river Minho . This influence is clearly shown by the remains of the Roman villa which can be found north of Pontevedra along the coast and by the aqueduct which was discovered in 1984 in As Neves in Santiago de Compost. Around 410 , the Roman legions left the Galician coast , which opened the region to the barbarian tribes . Birds have a very efficient system for diffusing oxygen into the blood ; birds have a ten times greater surface area to gas exchange volume than mammals . As a result it takes far less fornication of oxygen to the muscles in the flight . Bird ’ s air sacs do provide a limited oxygen supply during periods with little or no wing-beats . An air sac is a space within an animal that does not serve any other purpose that is lined with a layer of membrane and allows the diffusion of gas across the membrane . The air sacs of birds are an extension of the respiratory system . The air sacs are divided into a group of posterior air sacs and a group of anterior air sacs . The air sacs occupy a significant portion of the body of birds and are the sites of gas exchange . The anterior air sacs supply the lungs with air which is then transported to the posterior sacs by several sets of feathered blood vessels . The posterior air sacs consist of upwards of one hundred bags .

Egocentrism in adolescents forms a self-conscious desire to feel important in their peer groups and enjoy social acceptance . Unlike the conflicting aspects of self-concept , identity represents a coherent picture of self that takes into account aspects that are private and public ( p. 363 ) . Identity development is a unique individual process in which adolescents ' search for self-identity is primarily driven by interpersonal concerns . Egocentrism is the belief and attitude of individuals where only they have the right and only they can make right decisions on their behalf . Egocentrism in adolescents arises during the search for a permanent sense of self when many conflicting messages are internalized from the family and society at large ( p. 24 ) . Egocentrism is a characteristic that is highly correlated with poor decision-making in adolescents , which is also associated with risk-seeking behavior . For these reasons , egocentrism is believed by clinicians and researchers alike to interfere with the development of healthy relationships and a positive self-image in the adolescent . To better understand how adults identify healthy , functioning individuals from their egocentric counterparts , it is imperative to explore and understand the motivating factors behind individual 's decision-making capacity for egocentric decisions .

Hong Taiji 's bureaucracy was staffed with many Han Chinese , including many newly surrendered Ming officials . The Manchus ' continued dominance was ensured by an ethnic quota for all civilian and military offices , the number of Han posts increasing after the Shunzhi Emperor established Chinese rule in Beijing in 1644 . The quota was lowered after the 1660s , and was ended after the death of Qing Shunzhi . The Manchurian- Han quota continued in the military at the level of regimental commander until the end of the Qing Dynasty . The quota system was very successful in maintaining a semblance of Chinese bureaucracy , but many Han officials were appointed for administrative purposes rather than due to skill or education . Han Chinese The Han Chinese were greatly reduced in number , but unlike the Manchu and Mongol peoples , were allowed to retain their own culture and language . The Yongzheng Emperor 's policies , however , caused hardship for many Chinese people . He attempted to replace the system of land grants to the aristocracy with an elaborate feudal system based on military recruitment quotas , and also issued new regulations of the gentry in which a person had to qualify for all levels for which he may be eligible for appointment . A person who was appointed directly to a high position would have to prove that he was qualified for the lower positions first .

In contemporary society , adolescents also face some risks as their sexuality begins to transform . While some of these , such as emotional distress ( fear of abuse or failure to conform ) , anxiety disorders , etc , remain constant , others tend to lessen . At this moment , sexuality does not necessarily imply a risk . But let 's look at some of the dangers that adolescents face in society , both physical and mental . There are several mental risks that adolescents face . One of them is emotional distress , which is simply putting oneself in a state of fear or distress that would result from any sexual act . Whether it is emotional distress as a result of a lack of sexual knowledge , or from a sexual relationship with someone who is very different from you , it is a major risk for adolescents . There is also an important risk related to sexual abuse . At this age , the person is usually just as defenseless on an emotional level as on an intellectual level , and so if a victim of sexual abuse is aware of this fact , he or she can become overwhelmed very easily . Even if he or she has never been sexually abused , he or she can be in a situation where the victim is vulnerable ( fear of aggression , of losing his or her job , of not being believed , etc ) .

Like the reptiles , birds are primarily uricotelic , that is , their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia . This results in the formation of a white paste known as urates , instead of the usual urine that humans produce . Because uric acid is much less soluble than urea or ammonia , birds do not have the same challenges with urinary concentrations that humans are familiar with . Rather , uric acid is excreted as a white paste that requires virtually no water to leave the body , which makes sense considering that water is somewhat of a scarcity in an arid environment . This also has the benefit of not concentrating urine which may prevent kidney damage . Birds can not , however , concentrate the urine to help them regulate the ionic composition of their blood . This is why birds , like reptiles , have few problems with dehydration , as they do not retain water the way that most mammals do after drinking . Another major physiological differences between birds and mammalian kidneys is the structure of the glomerulus and the presence of glomerular capsule .

Unlike the Spanish milled dollar the U.S. dollar is based upon a decimal system of values . In addition to the dollar the coinage act officially established monetary units of fifty cents , twenty-five cents , ten cents , five cents , and one cent . It was the first major attempt to establish a single standard . The next major step was the gold standard . The gold standard linked the value of paper money to a specific amount of gold . In the 1930s President Franklin Delano Roosevelt closed the nation ’ s gold window and stopped the exchange of U. S. dollars for gold . After World War II the United States led the move to establish a new , internationally accepted standard . A conference of more than 40 nations adopted the Bretton Woods Agreement , which established the International Monetary Fund to support exchange rates with gold - backed currencies . Many modern specialty matches have been devised , with unique winning conditions . The most common of these is the ladder match . In the basic ladder match , the goal is for the wrestler who is at the top of a ladder when it is set up to retrieve the object . In this type of match , one ladder is set up in the ring at the designated beginning of the match . If the ladder is set up and is not on the mat when the bell rings , it must be completely inside the ropes . The match 's winner must hold and not drop the object held by said ladder from that time on until the match has ended . The object is generally a `` high-profile `` item such as a championship belt . Another variation of the standard ladder match is the two-on-one ladder match , which is often used as a qualifier for tournaments , and can be a precursor to the multi-tiered match . , the goal is for the winning team to be the first to retrieve a standard ladder .

One example of growth can be seen in the history of the residence halls . The University of Pennsylvania 's earliest halls housed only about 100 students , but in recent years have accommodated at least 1600 . The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo , signed on February 2 , 1848 , by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary representatives Luis G. Cuevas , Bernardo Couto , and Felipe Segundo Alvarez , concluded the War between the United States and Mexico , and the United States acknowledged the independence of the Republic of Texas . The United States gained about one-third of the territory of Mexico and acquired the region from the Rio Grande river to California . In accordance with the treaty 's specific terms and conditions , the entire frontier between the Texas-Mexico border and the Rocky Mountains was set as the boundary between the United States and Mexico . However , the area between the Rio Grande river and the southern border of Colorado was still an enigma , which led to a complicated territorial dispute between the former Mexican states of New Mexico and Chihuahua in 1859 and 1860 , the American War. The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was negotiated at the Guadalupe Hidalgo , at the outskirts of Mexico City , in western Mexico in the state of San Luis Potosi . # # Background of the 1845 Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo Since 1803 , Spain and the United States had reached several agreements regarding the boundary of the Louisiana Purchase .

The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate , as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons . On the day of the event , the sovereign is escorted into the Senate on a horse , while the House sits outside in the Senate Chamber as a salute is fired from the cannons on the steps of the House of Commons . The Constitution dictates that the sovereign must grant a Royal Assent in the name of the Canadian monarchy , or in the name of the Canadian person to whom the monarchy may vest . The Royal Assent by the sovereign does not guarantee the constitutionality of a bill and may be withheld if the bill is deemed to contravene the constitution or the monarch 's duty not to interfere in the functions of the elected legislature . In 1947 , when George VI dissolved Parliament in order to form a minority government , he personally withheld his royal assent to the last bill from the minority government . The most elegant approach to quantum mechanics is to treat the particles in the quantum system , however small or large , as excitations of an underlying field which permeates all of space . The field may be either a massless scalar field , a massive scalar or a vector . Massive scalar fields can not be treated as classical fields , but scalar quantum fields are a more familiar concept , and are treated as a continuous classical field . Although some classical field models have been very successful , it is usually difficult to get the theory into agreement with experiment .

At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste ( Cubist House ) , signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with a team of assistants . The latter became famous as one of the first modernist buildings . This work has become the most representative symbol of Cubism and modernism , the only one that has reached such a wide publicity , the only one that is completely preserved . Duchamp-Villon began to be interested in architecture , from 1914 , when he began working with the engineer Antoine-Marie Chabry and with the photographer and architect Paul Langevin . After his death in 1918 , Duchamp-Villon was succeeded by two famous photographers and architects : Henri Matisse and Le Corbusier . Duchamp-Villon 's contribution consisted mainly of drawings , models and prefabrication of parts , while Mare took care of the furniture , lighting fixtures and interior decorations . According to Matisse , his role was limited to making minor improvements to some elements ; moreover , at least according to the original project signed by Duchamp-Villon , Matisse was the creator of only two elements , a kind of stair. Diverse elements such as the caryatids of the stairs were designed by Mare , Matisse and Chabry .

It has become the dominant style of popular music throughout the world .

President Truman , symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president , again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat . It was only after the Supreme Court handed down its Brown v. Board of Education decision and he had begun to see changes in domestic policy , especially in the area of civil rights , that he finally responded to Truman ’ s calls and ran . Ike also saw in the Democrats the beginnings of a more socially liberal party , something he never could embrace . When Eisenhower ran for president in 1952 , his campaign was largely controlled by the Republican leaders in the House and Senate , who viewed him as a candidate to restore the party ’ s dignity in an era increasingly dominated by the scandals of the. By the late 1950s , Eisenhower had come to realize fully the limitations of his party ’ s southern wing. The 1960 Republican platform , written by Republicans from the South , struck Eisenhower as too conservative ( and in his words “ too isolationist ” ) . Though it rejected civil rights , it reaffirmed the party ’ s “ wholehearted support ” of segregation — something Eisenhower , with his recent experience in the South , found intolerable .

The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem . Self-esteem is defined as one 's thoughts and feelings about one 's self-concept and identity . Most theories on self-esteem revolve around the idea of self-love and the love of others . Theories on self-esteem are based around the idea that self-esteem must be both acceptable to others as well as appropriate to the self in order to function properly and produce happiness in the individual . It must also be pointed out , however , that because so many aspects of identity are interwoven with one another that there is an interdependency and interaction between the different aspects . This is because of the constant interplay between the inner self and the outer world . It can therefore be concluded that not only do different aspects of identity affect one another but also that aspects of identity affect self-esteem and one 's identity as it is interwoven with others . When one 's cultural identity is negatively impacted , the positive self - concept and self - image can quickly be shattered if not addressed properly . A common result of intercultural transplants is the interruptions or negative impacts on self -concept and self- image .

The Montana Territory was formed on April 26 , 1864 , when the U.S. passed the Organic Act . Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory after a meeting in the state capitol Helena of the people who were in charge of overseeing the territory . The first high school in Montana was the Montana Territorial Normal School and Commercial College , known simply as Montana Normal College . Montana Normal College only lasted five years , but it was the first building in Montana to be funded and operated by the federal government . It served as the state ’ s first high school , junior college , and teacher college . However , it didn ’ t last long , and Montana ’ s high schools have developed and moved into separate buildings in different cities and counties throughout the state since its creation . # # # # High school in Montana from 1864 up until 1880 The first teachers who came to Montana to teach students about different subjects were usually men who would leave their families behind to help the development. On 20 June 1794 , Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat , being replaced by Thomas Erskine , his adversary in the trial . He retired to the country and devoted his time to study and literary activity . He is best remembered for his long series of speeches on parliamentary privilege in defense of the liberties of the press and the opposition of the Crown and the House of Lords to arbitrary interference by other branches of government , the most complete defense of those principles ever delivered. He also wrote his great historical masterpiece , the History of the French Revolution . Burke died on 27 October 1814 , in Woodcroft ( now part of the town of Woodcroft ) , Kent , England . His body was first buried in Chelsea Old Church , but in 1859 , Burke 's heart and skeleton were removed to rest in Westminster Abbey . Family Burke 's descendants include his namesake , Charles James Fox , leader of the Whigs in Parliament during the late 18th and early 19th centuries .

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California , Berkeley 's Institute of Human Development , formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare , in 1927 . The Institute was instrumental in the establishment of child health programs at the university . Macfarlane was a major force in the creation of community mental health centers . In 1935 , she became the first chairman of the Commission on Social Care of the Elderly appointed by the United States Congress . In 1940 , she was elected to serve in the U. S. In 1603 , that changed when the King of Scotland inherited the Crown of England , and consequently the Crown of Scotland as well ; James VI of Scotland was now James I of England . England and Scotland were still separate countries , with separate Parliaments , but for the first time their common King was able to unite them politically . The Acts of Union 1719 ( Scotland ) and the Acts of Union 1800 ( UK ) amalgamated the Scottish and English / British Parliaments into the UK Parliament . One result of the Union was the creation of a single set of laws for the whole territory ; these included Acts of Parliament which have now become Scots law . The legal system of Scotland continues to develop through judgments of the Scottish courts and Acts of parliament . When John 's elder brother Richard became king in September 1189 , he had already declared his intention of joining the Third Crusade . Richard set about raising the huge sums of money necessary for such an enterprise and also tried to establish a united front of European kings to support his plans . However , his French and German barons in particular were reluctant to support a lengthy and expensive crusade . Therefore Richard decided to carry out a short , speedy campaign in the hope that he would capture the strategically vital port of Jaffa . Once the port was secured he planned to return home via the Holy Land and seek another campaign elsewhere in 1192 when all Crusaders were welcome to join him . On Easter eve 1190 when Richard first sailed from Marseilles , he found himself accompanied by only two hundred ships and had to leave most of his Crusaders behind . On arriving in Acre , Richard tried to secure the allegiance of King Baldwin in return for the return of all money owed to Richard by the crusades of King Henry II but Baldwin refused the offer . After several weeks of futile wrangling there was a sudden change in direction .

Usually a Presbyterian church will not have statues of saints , nor the ornate altar more typical of a Roman Catholic church . Instead , one will find a `` communion table or an altar cross . `` A common feature found in all Presbyterian churches are two identical pulpits on either side of the main entrance . These pulpits are identical in appearance and purpose . The two pulpits have a great deal of sacred symbolism . One may refer to them also as a `` choir loft '' . Unlike the pulpit of an Anglican church , the Presbyterian pulpit does not have an elaborate lectern . Usually the pulpit is positioned high above the main portion of the sanctuary or at the front of the choir where it may be closer to the congregation . During special services such as a baptism or Holy Communion , the two preachers may use the pulpit at the same time . This is a reminder that Christ gives us one body of believers and two equal ministers of the gospel message . Because it is located at the leading edge of the sanctuary , some say that the center of the pulpit also represents the `` center of the Christian universe .

From the 8th to the 10th century , three dynasties contested for control of northern India : the Gurjara Pratiharas of Malwa , the Palas of Bengal , and the Rashtrakutas of Gujarat . It was during this period that the Harisbuddha , a Buddhist pilgrimage center , arose on Mount Abu to commemorate the conversion of Rajendra I . The 11th and 12th centuries saw the arrival of the Chandela kingdom of Central India , the Yadava dynasty of Devagiri , and the Chalukya dynasty of southern Karnataka . Under Pandyas , Rajaraja Chola I and his son , Rajendra Chola II , ruled southern India from the eleventh to the thirteenth centuries . Alla and Bijaya Râja of the Yadava dynasty controlled the Deccan . The Chandela kingdom , which included Bundelkhand and Central India , was the most powerful of these dynasties . After a long period of disintegration and decline , the Chandelas were replaced in the middle of the 12th century by the Pratihara dynasty of the Paramara , which extended its rule to a large part of northern. The early history of the Chandelas is obscure .

Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War , the effects of the conflict were profound , both at home and abroad . Much of Europe lay in ruins , and , in the case of Germany and Japan , the effects were devastating . For Britain , the war brought both hardship and prosperity . The cost , in dollars , of the war was estimated to be as much as $ 130 billion , roughly equivalent to more than $ 1. 3 trillion today . But , because the British military , despite early losses , had proven remarkably successful overall , their status within the world community had been enhanced . The war had also strengthened the empire , especially in the Middle East and Africa , where a growing number of countries were moving towards self-government within the Commonwealth . In 1949 , one year after the end of the conflict , the United Nations was created to provide a central platform for international cooperation . This new structure provided a space for the countries that had recently won their freedom from their colonial masters to discuss issues on an equal footing .

Although people often think that memory operates like recording equipment , it is not the case . The molecular mechanisms underlying the induction and maintenance of memory are very dynamic and their study is difficult because memory is very susceptible to interference . However , it is clear that some molecular processes are involved in the formation of the memory of certain events , which can later be activated , for example , when a similar stimulus is applied : In this way , the memory lasts longer ,. From an evolutionary perspective , the importance of memory is evident . Animals need to have mechanisms to remember , remember and recognize the stimuli they encounter . Humans also benefit from being able to remember . Indeed , the ability to remember allows humans to learn to distinguish objects and to distinguish between good , bad or neutral events , . In addition [ , ] , it has been demonstrated that memories can be preserved without any traces of the original stimulus . Some animals can remember a new food that they would never find again and can remember their home even if they have never returned .

Following the fall of Wu and the turmoil of the Wu Hu uprising against the Jin dynasty ( 265–420 ) , most of elite Chinese families had collaborated with the Wu Hu in hope of benefitting from the new order or had been slaughtered in the chaos . Liu Yujing , the last ruler of the Jin dynasty , had fled deep into the south where he and his family had ruled from Jiankang ( now Nanjing ) . The Yin had been a local Chinese regime set up by the family of Liu Yujing and they had ruled for 44 years under the name of Wu until the last of the Yin had finally been extinguished by. The last king of the Wu Hu , Sun Shao , had been forced to flee with his family into exile from Jingjiang ( now Hangzhou ) , in the year 263 . On his way home , he was surrounded and slaughtered by Liu Xian . In order to appease Liu Xian , Liu Yuheng then arranged the marriage of Liu Xian and the deceased emperor of the Wu Hu to his daughter , Sun Yilun , for purposes of peace in the year. Sun Yilun had finally been able to successfully flee into her exile at Jingjiang along with Liu Yuheng and his brothers , where she set up the first of the Sun regimes from the year to the year.

A common way in which emotions are conceptualized in sociology is in terms of the multidimensional characteristics including cultural or emotional labels ( e.g. , anger , pride , fear ) , intensity ( e. g. , mild , intense ) , timing ( e. g. , brief , sustained ) , and expression ( e. g. , public , private ) 4 . The concept of emotional literacy emerged in educational debates of the early 1980s , initially in relation to the teaching of English in the UK . Several different models of emotional intelligence have also developed since 1990 . However , the concept has been particularly influential in educational research and policy , as an alternative means of defining and measuring intelligence which takes an individual ’ s emotional development into account alongside their cognitive and social development . 3 . A critical view of emotional literacy approaches The concept of emotional literacy developed through an interest in the role of affect , emotions and emotional expression in everyday social life , initially in relation to language development and the development of self and. Emotional literacy ( also called emotional intelligence ) is the capacity to monitor , recognise , understand , and manage our feelings , attitudes and emotional reactions .

Darwin was hard at work on his `` big book '' on Natural Selection , when on 18 June 1858 he received a parcel from Wallace , who stayed on the other side of the world at the time . In the parcel was a manuscript entitled `` On the Tendency of Races to acquire modified form s through the natural selection of advantageous variations `` by Alfred Russel Wallace . Early editions of Darwin ' s On the Origin of Species ( 1859 ) mistakenly credited Wallace as the co-author . The letter was received by T . H . Huxley from Edward Hooker 's house at Twickenham in Middlesex . An encyclical published in 1835 by Pope Gregory XVI declared the idea of a `` social equality among various races of man `` both `` false and dangerously pernicious `` and therefore `` condemned for ever ( see Catholic. com ) . In 1866 , Wallace published The Malay Archipelago , a book based on his collections during his journeys in Indonesia and the Pacific islands . Wallace observed in the book that many animals `` have been developed and modified specially , in order thereby to render them perfectly fitted , both in structure and in the arrangements of their organs , for exploiting the natural resources of their particular habitats.

Early Modern universities initially continued the curriculum and research of the Middle Ages : natural philosophy , logic , medicine , theology , mathematics , astronomy ( and astrology ) and law . In the 15th century , a new important academic discipline emerged : humanism , in the context of the Renaissance , which focused on the study of classical culture . The study of the humanities and arts in early modern higher education expanded from the study of grammar and rhetoric to the study of languages , literature , history , and philosophy ( natural philosophy , moral philosophy , political philosophy , and metaphysics. ) In the 16th century , the study of science began to become a recognized academic discipline , particularly following the emergence of experimental science and the application of new technologies , beginning in the 16th century at the University of Padua ( with the emergence of. ) The study of natural history began at the late 15th century University of Naples Federico II and the University of Bologna . A typical university of the 16th century included law as a mandatory course .

Fearing the worst , the Romans began a major mobilization , all but pulling out of recently pacified Spain and Gaul . They even established a major garrison in Sicily , and with many troops on the island , it was not yet considered lost . During the campaign of Aemilius Lepidus , the fleet of Roman consul L. Marcius Philippus , defeated a superior Carthaginian fleet , bringing about the collapse of the Carthaginian naval power as well as the main Carthaginian base in North Africa ( Tunis ) . Hannibal was defeated in Cannae , a major victory for the Romans , and his own army broken . He fled into Italy where he stayed for 16 years , until the Romans found him and captured him near Capua and he was brought back to Rome under heavy guard . After this , the Romans turned their attention towards Africa . The 2nd Punic War had a decisive impact on the life of Rome . The Republic faced many problems : the city was overcrowded , its grain supply was threatened when Sicily and Sardinia were lost , the threat from Carthage was still severe , the whole Mediterranean area had become hostile. The 2nd Punic War is also considered the first conflict in which the Romans began to think of themselves as a major power .

Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent 's life . For example , menarche ( the first menstrual period of a woman ) and the first orgasm are often considered to be sexual awakenings in female humans . Similarly , the time of onset of pubic and underarm hair , the development of male secondary sex sexuality , and the ability of boys to ejaculate are signs of impending adulthood . The first act of sexual intercourse is viewed by many cultures as the key event in establishing adult sexual identity as well as in the transition into adulthood . The political structure of Western Europe changed with the end of the united Roman Empire . Although the movements of peoples during this period are usually described as `` invasions `` by outsiders , the truth is that these migrations were conducted largely in the name of a Roman emperor . However , Roman administrative control over Europe became progressively looser , until the early Middle Ages when no power extended beyond the frontiers of the Empire except for limited control of the sea . Then it was the Germanic tribes , moving west from the steppes , whose military conquests transformed the political topography of Western Europe . There was no one single `` migration `` in the form of a concerted movement of Germanic tribes in pursuit of specific goals ; instead , a number of invasions and migrations , sometimes involving a major ethnic group , sometimes not , were carried out on. The invasions and migration of the Germanic peoples occurred over a long period of time and in various waves ; it is unclear when these movements stopped being voluntary expeditions , and when the German peoples were forced to move because of a. The barbarian invasions of the Roman Empire began in 376 A.

Comprehensive schools have been accused of grade inflation after a study revealed that Gymnasium senior students of average mathematical ability found themselves at the very bottom of their class and being placed into lower grade groups . The research has shown that the differences between high and low ability students were widening . “ The level of differentiation inside Austrian schools has reached a crisis point . This is because schools have tried to cater for students at different levels , and there is a higher requirement on the lower end , ” said University of Vienna education professor Hanns Langegger . “ These schools are like a bus , they have to carry the students on different routes , so they are going much slower than they otherwise would , and the higher achievement level and standard in the upper grades remains relatively unchanged or is improving only slightly ,. The end result is that the lower standard in lower grades is getting worse , ” . The research also showed that more students in Austria are failing to pass national exams , called Matura , that school leaving is compulsory after 15 years in school . For example , in 1991 80 percent of students with an average score passed the maths Matura exam .

The university culture developed differently in northern Europe than it did in the south , although the northern ( primarily Germany , France and Great Britain ) and southern universities differ significantly . The universities of the south , and later also in Italy and Spain , were usually founded by the church and under the protection of the emperor , the nobility or the city . There were , however , always tensions between the university and the state . The German universities , in contrast , were mainly based on the power and funding of monarchs and aristocrats . Initially they were the training grounds of the elite , who could thus use their influence to advance and ensure their sons a university education . This model then spread over the rest of Germany and parts of northern Europe . The state had an interest in the universities that was not reflected by its own funding . Universities as institutions of higher learning were largely shaped by the development of the bourgeoisie . The universities of northern Europe , in contrast , took on the form of autonomous institutions of the state .

The Yale Report of 1828 was a dogmatic defense of the Latin and Greek curriculum against critics who wanted more courses in modern languages , mathematics , and science . It was signed by an impressive list of scholars . When first published , the Report received considerable attention . Several years later , other scholars . Among them was Horace Mann , who went on to become prominent in the public school movement . To begin with , the Report argued that Latin and Greek , in the light of then - current scholarship , were two necessary foundations for any higher education . Further , it was argued that the training in logic and rhetoric that the ancient languages brought about was essential to the development of a student 's mind . The Report thus rejected calls for `` reform , `` which it associated with a `` democratic `` mentality , as well as with a neglect of the ancient heritage and of the mind 's own higher development . The Report also rejected the idea that students should be trained to do practical work .

Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease . In a microbial culture , a growth medium is provided for a specific agent . A sample taken from the patient 's body will provide a growth medium that has microorganisms present in a suspension ( if the disease requires a direct inoculation of some microorganism ) . Some microorganisms ( such as Mycobacteria ) require a special medium with a carbon source for successful growth , whereas others ( like Gram-positive bacteria ) do not require any special culture . For example in bacterial cultures , the growth medium often consists of tryptone ( which is made up of protein ) . Yeast or egg material may be introduced in culture for fungal cultures , but blood is used for mammalian cultures . Անդրեյան , Յ . Microbial Diversity , 8 th ed , Wiley < /s >. While medieval pageants and festivals such as Corpus Christi were church-sanctioned , Carnival was also a manifestation of medieval folk culture . Many local Carnival customs are claimed to derive from this folk tradition , such as the wearing of masks , parades , or costumes . The earliest historical record of a European Carnival is from Venice in 1296–99 AD , where the festival acquired strong associations with the Republic ’ s history and identity . The Venice Carnival , which is still celebrated on an annual basis , eventually spread to many other Italian cities . The tradition of “ mardi gras ” has existed since the Middle Ages , when it commemorated the Carnival season , a time of social upheaval and the suspension of normal values and behavior . In modern times , Mardi Gras , which is celebrated on the day before Ash Wednesday , has become a public holiday in several areas of the world , particularly the Americas , the Caribbean , India , and Brazil . әnə Carnival is defined as an annual festival and celebration on the eve of Lent , characterized by parades , masquerading , and merrymaking .

Adolescence marks a rapid change in one 's role within a family . Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully , but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family decision - making , except in their own limited area of behavior . In contrast adolescents may become the most influential members of the family in some respects , and may be highly dissatisfied with the decisions , or even the expectations , of parents . However , the research literature concerning the family decision - making process in the adolescent era has been characterized by three features , which I will discuss here in somewhat greater detail . One is the relative lack of attention paid in the research literature to adolescent influences on the process . This contrasts starkly with the research that examines family decision-making in the child or adult period . Although various scholars have speculated about adolescent influence - making , it is only in the last few years that a systematic empirical examination of the adolescent process has been undertaken . My study of a family in which a decision about the educational future of a daughter was under discussion makes a fresh contribution by providing some insight into the process at work .

The late 1980s saw a series of liberalising economic reforms within Libya designed to cope with the decline in oil revenues . In May 1987 , Gaddafi announced the start of the “ People ’ s Conference ” , involving a four-stage plan . This envisaged a gradual transition to a more modern and developed Libyan economy based on a free market and private business . The first objective was to boost the Libyan economy , with an emphasis on tourism and agriculture . The second was an increase in trade with other countries , for the purpose of diversification . The third stage was a reduction in the number of foreign businesses operating in Libya , in favor of developing the national economy . Finally , the fourth stage was envisaged to be the adoption of a foreign investment law to attract investment . This process is being guided by an agency headed by the former president of the National Economic Development Board ( NEDB ) , Saleh Saadi . The reform program has made significant progress with the privatisation/compensation of state-owned enterprises , the abolition of the State Oil Corporation , liberalisation of agriculture , opening of ports to foreign capital and the adoption of a draft foreign investment law .

On December 8 , 1991 , at Viskuli near Brest ( Belarus ) , the President of the Russian SFSR and the heads of Byelorussian SSR and Ukrainian SSR signed the Belavezha Accords . The signing of the Belavezha Accords effectively brought an end to the Soviet Union , which dissolved almost exactly two decades later . On August 24 , 1991 , coup plotters forced Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev out of the Crimean capital Yalta and declared him removed from the presidential seat . By doing so the plotters also dissolved the Supreme Soviet , the last constitutionally recognised body in the Soviet Union . Boris Yeltsin became the Russian head of state and effectively took Gorbachev ’ s place at the helm of the all-Soviet government . Yeltsin claimed the title of president the following year . On August 20 , Gorbachev was released from house arrest by Russian military authorities and announced that he was still in charge of the Republic of Russia and the Soviet Union . While in Moscow he met with Yeltsin who said that he ( Yeltsin ) would take matters of state governance into his own hands in the name of Soviet President .

The European concept of `` race '' , along with many of the ideas now associated with the term , arose at the time of the scientific revolution , which began in the mid-17th century . The term `` race `` was used to refer to distinct biological groups that were different from those of other peoples in various aspects . For example , Johann Blumenbach ( 1752–1840 ) , a prominent German anatomist and anthropologist , suggested in 1795 that there were three main races – white ( Caucas. White ) , yellow ( Mongoloid ) and black ( Negroid ) . Others disagreed . Some asserted that there were four or five races . In France , George-Louis Leclerc , Comte de Buffon ( 1707–1788 ) , a well-known naturalist and scientist , used the term `` races `` to describe the wide range of. variations of the human species . But he did not use the term race as the name of distinct biological groups . Nevertheless , the writings of Jean-Jacques Rousseau ( 1712–1778 ) and others influenced French culture to such a degree that it was assumed that all human beings could be classified as belonging to.

The Space Race was a 20th-century competition between two Cold War rivals , the Soviet Union ( USSR ) and the United States ( US ) , for supremacy in space exploration . The race was primarily the result of superpower rivalry , driven by opposing geopolitical interests , which became known as the Space Race in the early 1960s after the failed US attempt to put a man on the Moon. The rivalry continued until both sides achieved an understanding , marked by the Apollo–Soyuz Test Project , which was seen as a final step in detente . The two superpowers had competed in a range of fields since the advent of nuclear weapons in World War II . However , the race was sparked chiefly by technological advances in missile technology in the 1950s . Green is also one of the most popular colors for restaurants , bars and clubs ( and the most frequently used for food and beverages ) and also for office work . In the Far East . After Cassander 's death in 298 BCE , however , Demetrius , who still maintained a sizable loyal army and fleet , invaded Macedon , seized the Macedonian throne ( as Demetrius II of Macedon ) , and restored the previous territorial integrity of that state ( with the exception of Epiros and Thessaly ) . He was thus the first of the Hellenistic kings to expand Macedonian territory , creating a great empire that stretched as far as the Persian Gulf . This expansion included the complete destruction of Epiros , except Olynthus , and the subsequent colonisation of this area by Macedonian citizens . From here on , however , Demetrius ’ reign is marred with treachery , rebellion and civil war . During his struggle against Pyrrhus , his Macedonian subjects became more and more restive . In 285 he fell a victim to the intriguing , rebellious queen , Phthia , who had him put to death while he was on his way to Epirus to meet Pyrrhus , and handed over Macedon. The next king , Antigonus , had the body of his late brother put to flight and placed him in the tomb at Nemea .

Successful cultivation of cotton requires a long frost-free period , plenty of sunshine , and a moderate rainfall , usually from 600 to 1,200 mm ( 24 to 47 in ) . Cotton does not tolerate excessive wet ness , nor does it withstand long periods of dry . It thrives wherever these conditions exist . Cotton requires warm soil temperatures to produce satisfactory yields and quality , with 65 to 70 °F ( 18 to 21°C ) being the optimal temperature for seed germination . The optimum soil pH for cotton growth is 6. 5 . The ideal range for pH is 6 . Cotton , also called upland cotton , is a native of tropical America and has become a fiber of worldwide importance . Cotton grows in a variety of climatic conditions . Most U. S . cotton is grown on the warm South central United States . Cotton is generally a self pollinating plant and therefore normally does not require hand pollination . < /s >. Cotton is a major export commodity in Pakistan .

Mary 's complete sinlessness and concomitant exemption from any taint from the first moment of her existence was a doctrine familiar to Greek theologians of Byzantium . Beginning with St. Maximus the Confessor in the seventh century , however , this doctrine acquired prominence , and some theologians ascribed to her a `` preservation from sin '' from the very womb ( preservationis a sinu ) . In the twelfth and thirteenth centuries , the issue became the most discussed one in the Orient . The Greek controversy over the Assumption began in 1274 , when the emperor Michael Paleologos made a vow not to marry until the relics of Mary were discovered at Ephesus . He asked the patriarch of Constantinople , Germanos I , whether relics had been discovered at Ephesus . Germanos , who was the first Greek Catholic patriarch , was unwilling to give him an answer which might be interpreted as his own opinion . He therefore replied simply that such a question should be put to an ecumenical council . In October 2014 , the trial of six senior staff and journalists at The Sun newspaper began . All six were charged with conspiring to commit misconduct in a public office by paying police officers for information , and all six pleaded not guilty . The prosecution claimed that officers at The Sun had regularly committed corruption offences in order to find and reveal out information about celebrities and others of interest to the publication . The Crown Prosecution Service , based on the evidence of two female officers who worked for The Suns investigative team , said this had created a culture where the officers received gifts or cash in exchange for compromising evidence . One of those arrested and charged was then-photojournalist Alan Mullally , who was also a staff photographer with The Sun newspaper . Mullally , who worked at The Sun for over 20 years , was charged with conspiracy with another Sun journalist ( Gerard Brand and others ) in July 2013 , a year after the Sun went bust. A number of high - profile celebrity figures were among those whose stories were allegedly obtained by officers at the Sun .

The initial military maneuvers began in September 1806 . In a notable letter to Marshal Soult detailing the plan for the campaign , Napoleon described the essential features of Napoleonic warfare : `` . In no circumstances are troops ever to stand still without occupation . '' In order to achieve this aim of occupying enemy territory , Napoleon sought to deploy troops in columns and waves . Throughout the maneuvers , the army practiced infantry and artillery fire , marching , counter-attacking , pursuit and encirclement . This practice laid the foundations for the Napoleonic army . Flavius Josephus ( 7th century A. D. ) reported that the Romans practiced maneuvers to hone and maintain battle skills , and the first military encampment in the United States , to learn the art of war , was established in Cambridge , Massachusetts , in 1637. However , these military camps are different from the `` cantonments `` established by Napoleon to train his army . Cantonment , meaning `` camp , `` came from military parlance and began as a temporary encampment until 1793 when Napoleon , then commander of the National Guard , converted the cantonments into training camps . In 1794 , he ordered all troops to form cantonments at a set time .

Chopin made several trips to Paris with Mendelssohn ; on 26 September 1834 , he gave a series of public demonstrations of his piano playing at Le Parc in Boulogne-Billancourt . Chopin composed `` The Minute Waltz `` during this period . In 1834 , his `` Ballade in G Minor `` was dedicated to his patroness , Countess d ’ Aguilera , and it was during this year that Chopin began writing the Polonaise in Ab . He wrote to Titus Woyciechowski , one in a series of dedicated letters : ` My dear Titus , your letter is one of the warmest things you ever wrote to me , and it gives me a great deal of pleasure . It so happens that I ’ ve written some Polonaises and have only to finish them .
