Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker by choice , a member of a minority group , on the inside of a minority group who does n ’ t feel at ease with his culture ( Ferd , 2013 ) . It follows that “ it is important to understand the nuances and the meanings attributable to the concept of exclusion in order to try to avoid the inexorable effects linked to marginality “ ( Sofia Lia ,. 2007 , p. 40 ) . It is also possible that an “ inclusive “ boundary can emerge when a person who is considered as belonging to a certain category or social group , develops an attitude , behavior or belief that defines him as a member of that group . Thus , some people , for example , could feel excluded when meeting a group of people who are in close contact and exclaim “ you must be my friend ! ” ( Ferd , 2013 ) . The boundaries can also be excluding when the group is perceived as being a small community of people .

To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet . While the earliest mammals were probably predators , different species have adapted to eating a range of different foods . Most mammals belong to the placental group ; placentals are able to feed their young from an internal organ that facilitates the transfer of substances from one organism to another . In the case of humans , the placenta provides oxygen and nutrients to the developing baby through its umbilical cord . Some placental mammals use this adaptation to pass antibodies through to the child while it is developing in the womb . Another benefit of using a placenta is to protect mothers from the risk of contracting an infection from the foetus . There are also other groups of mammals that do not use a placenta to nourish their young . One example are marsupials , in which the embryos are only semi–developed when born . Because reproduction is energy intensive , it is assumed that reproductively active species should have more developed metabolisms than other animals . However , there is an apparent trend where the more developed and complex the metabolism , the less energy the organism can produce as a whole .

In 2012 , Abigail Fisher , an undergraduate student at Louisiana State University , and Rachel Multer Michalewicz , a law student at Southern Methodist University , filed a lawsuit against the University of Texas at Austin . The two filed the lawsuit on the basis that they did not receive admission because of the Affirmative Action Program at the university . The lawsuit alleged that the university ’ s use of race in the admission process violates Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 , as well as the Fourteenth Amendment . The lawsuit was initially filed in the District Court of Austin , Texas . The U. S. District Court for the District of Columbia overturned the case that held that the policy at the University is a violation of Title VI ( 4 F. Supp . 3d 654 ) . The ruling was set aside by the Fifth Circuit and a rehearing denied . They had their case heard by the United States Supreme Court . On June 23 , 2016 , the Supreme Court ruled that Texas ’ university ’ s admissions program did not violate Title VI , which is good news for the students who have applied to the school .

To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing , sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated . This is achieved by Neutral Sections ( Neutral Grounds ) . The current leaving a neutral section must be the same as the current returning . In addition to Neutral Sections , the feeder station supply to sections of line is often divided into two separate circuits so that any faults in either will ensure current does not carry to other sections of line . Another important concern is the amount of short circuit current delivered to a feeder station . This will decide the design of the switchgear at the station and the size of the transformers used . The short circuit current on an oil-free , dry circuit is usually limited to 0. 16 A but if there are insulated conductors that are likely to be broken under fault conditions , it may be necessary to limit this to 0. 2 A . The minimum size of a transformer is dependent on the short circuit current delivered .

Asian Americans in New York City , according to the 2010 Census , number more than one million , greater than the combined totals of San Francisco and Los Angeles. However , they remain a comparatively small , and often poor , segment of the city ’ s population . This community is a diverse collection of East and South Asians that trace their immigration histories to at least four distinct “ waves ” of entry to the city . This is by no means a complete history of Asian Americans in New York . Rather , it traces the contours of specific immigrant experiences , and the ways in which individual stories intersect and become part of a larger narrative . Asian immigration to New York has been a long , and often difficult , process . The experience of Asian immigrants differed in the immediate aftermath of immigration , before assimilation into the wider society , and after . This experience has also varied based on gender as well as region of origin in Asia . New York ’ s political , economic , and social contexts shaped the destinies of these immigrants , and at the same time , immigrants reshaped the city ’ s social and cultural landscape .

These coffeehouses became fashionable gathering places for Parisians to socialize . Since then , the café became a part of the French culture , as well as a social institution as it still is in the 21st century . The cafe is a symbol of the French culture . The famous Café de Flore , where the Declaration of the Second Republic was signed is today the location of `` Le Monde `` . Paris is also famous for its cafés that feature unique menus . One of the most popular are the French brasseries , restaurants that feature steaks , seafood and seafood appetizers , baked potatoes , and onion soup . Restaurants are also famous for their French cuisine : beef Bourguignon , which is a stew of beef , wine , garlic , carrots , mushrooms , onions and served over rice or bread .

Dorgon 's controversial July 1645 edict ( the `` haircutting order '' ) forced adult Han Chinese men to shave the front of their heads and comb the remaining hair in a queue , in a manner similar to that of Manchu men . This policy , known as manchuization , was an attempt by the Manchu leaders to impose uniformity among the three distinct Chinese groups . After the Jingbian Rebellion of 1655 , Dorgon 's successors issued additional manchuization decrees , ordering Han Chinese in several provinces to wear the Manchu hairstyle and the traditional Manchu dress . The Han Chinese responded in three phases . Firstly , many Han adopted Manchu customs , including hairstyle and fashion . Secondly , between 1645 and 1648 , many Han Chinese rose up in peasant rebellions , the best known being the Rebellion of Dahu and Chuzhou . These revolts spread across the country . The imperial Manchu government , under the leadership of Shunzhi , launched crackdowns of the rebellions . Finally , the Han Chinese , now mostly living in Manchuria following earlier migrations from the provinces of the North China Plain , established the Republic of China in 1912 and established diplomatic and economic ties with the Chinese Q.

The relationships adolescents have with their peers , family , and members of their social sphere play a vital role in the social development of an adolescent . As an adolescent develops socially , they learn how to communicate more effectively and successfully interact with other people , which is influenced by the connections they make and how they interact with those connections . Adolescent development is complex , and the social aspects of an adolescent ’ s life play a critical role in that development . # # Peer Relationships Friendships and peer relationships are an important part of a young person ’ s development in many ways . Adolescents are at a stage where learning how to trust others and develop friendships is an essential part of their growth . It is especially important to help adolescents understand how to deal with issues related to relationships , such as social anxiety and learning how to communicate effectively . # Family Relationships Another important aspect of social development is the relationship an adolescent has with their family members . It is important for adolescents to continue to develop their ability to problem solve and communicate with their family members .

Most fatty acids are non-essential , meaning the body can produce them as needed , generally from other fatty acids and always by expending energy to do so . However , the fatty acids considered essential are so-called because the body can not synthesize them from others and must receive them in the diet . These fatty acids are polyunsaturated and essential fatty acids ( EFA ) are linoleic acid omega-6 ( n-6 ) and alpha-linoleic acid omega-3 ( n-3 ). In addition to being essential for infants and children , especially , EFA are necessary for the development of the nervous system . In both cases , the diet must provide a balance of fatty acids , a topic not very clear . Fatty acids that provide energy Fatty acids can be classified in two ways . One , according to the number of double bonds , either are called saturated fatty acids for their chain and hydrogen atoms , to be considered neutral or even slightly fatty acids , or polyunsaturated if they are polyuns. Unsaturated fatty acids ( PUFA ) are an important source of energy .

Following the Sergeant Isaac Woodard incident , President Harry S. Truman , himself a combat veteran of World War I , issued Executive Order 9808 establishing the President 's Committee on Civil Rights . Truman 's order created a body to investigate the causes of racial discrimination and to make recommendations for action . President Lyndon B. Johnson appointed a national commission to study race relations between whites and blacks and to make policy proposals . The commission , of 14 members including 6 black members , was formed on October 18 , 1967 and reported in 1968 . The Civil Rights Act of 1968 , often called the Fair Housing Act or Title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 , was President Johnson 's response to the commission report and a companion measure was passed by the US Congress . The passage of the laws was the culmination of a movement that had begun a quarter of a century earlier and had included court decisions and grassroots legislation . Although both measures were passed and signed into law by President Lyndon Johnson , the initial efforts of civil rights activists were spearheaded by the Congress of Racial Equality ( CORE ) , with its project of Freedom Rides.

Protestants also took the initiative in advocating for religious freedom . Freedom of conscience had high priority on the theological , philosophical , and political agendas since Luther refused to support the Emperor Charles V 's plan to use the Reichstag ( a. k. a. Diet ) as an instrument for his imperial religious policy . The Protestants established their church as a political organization in the early 17th century . The Church of Sweden , the Church of Norway , and the Lutheran Church in Finland were in direct competition with the Catholic state church . In 1571 , when the Polish Diet convened an Assembly of Churches to resolve a religious conflict , the church came to an agreement with the national government . Protestants gained some influence by organizing an alliance and joining the anti-Catholic coalition led by Frederick III of the Palatinate , Elector of the Rhine . Protestants , however , were eventually overpowered by other forces and in 1648 , in the Treaty of Westphalia , the Protestant states were obliged to recognize the Catholic state church , the Roman Catholic Church . Freedom of conscience was not recognized either .

Before the early 20th century , treatments for infections were based primarily on medicinal folklore . Mixtures with antimicrobial properties that were used in treatments of infections were described over the centuries . An early treatment for typhoid was found on the Dead Sea and a similar drug was found in the 1920s near Sodom . Herbal preparations for various ailments are referred to in the Bible . It was thought that herbalism and the use of plants as medicine , was the basis for pharmaceutical medicines of today . The development of effective medicines from plant bases dates back some thousands of years . The earliest reliable references to pharmaceuticals and pharmacology date to the time of the Sumerians . There has been a close relationship between pharmacology , plant pharmacology and ethnopharmacology [ 1-5 ] . These three fields of science , together with medicinal chemistry and botany , provide a basis for the development of effective modern medicines and their application in the clinical treatment of human disease . The major therapeutic groups of drugs are derived from two principal sources , the medicinal agents of nature , often derived by chemical analysis from plants and the man made / chemically synthesized agents .

In 1681 , in partial repayment of a debt , Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony . Despite the royal grant , Penn was heavily in debt , and he mortgaged his charter to Thomas Prence on condition that Prence aid Penn in settling the colony . In 1682 , Prence and the ship captains of the Penn fleet ( 11 ships with 1400 passengers ) organized themselves in Philadelphia to run the colony until Penn could pay off his debts and take control . The Philadelphia Proprietary , as they called themselves , was the chief representative of the merchant-planters in the New World and was the main rival of the Royal Proprietary , which was composed of powerful absentee investors . As a member of the Philadelphia Proprietary , Captain John Cook ( 1650-1737 ) sailed on the Mary to Philadelphia . The Philadelphia Proprietary 's headquarters was located at the Philadelphia Courthouse on Market Street and the `` Court House '' functioned as a customs house in the 1680s . At that time , Philadelphia was so uninhabited that the custom house was located in a private home .

Chapter XI deals with evidence from biogeography , starting with the observation that differences in flora and fauna from separate regions can not be explained by environmental differences alone ; for example , the same plants grow in both England and China , although the two regions are very different in climate . In addition to species differences , however , there is a consistent trend of increasing genetic discontinuity as one travels farther south , and the degree of genetic discontinuity within different island communities . Darwin also argued that it is not reasonable to assume that birds and mammals from similar climates , such as the English and Indian pipits , can have such different plumage without some genetic reason . This is the evidence that shows that species , from different regions , have been modified to suit their new environment . The fact that the process extends throughout the world suggests to Darwin that the modifications are similar and due to similar causes ( evolution ) . Finally , this also points to the development of a common ancestry on the basis of evolution .

As cellular metabolism/energy production requires oxygen , potentially damaging ( e.g. , mutation causing ) compounds known as free radicals can form . Most of these are oxidizers ( i.e. , atoms or compounds that strip electrons from other molecules ) . While some are harmless , others can alter protein , DNA and other molecules , causing harmful changes that lead to tissue injury and the development of certain diseases . A cell ’ s ability to withstand free radicals and maintain the delicate balance of metabolic processes ( so -called “ oxidative stress ” ) is regulated by endogenous compounds known as antioxidants ( usually protein or phenol based ) that “ neutralize ” potentially damaging free radicals . However , due to natural wear and tear , aging , or disease , ineffective antioxidant defense mechanisms lead to increased oxidative stress and cellular damage . While the body can replenish these antioxidants , the aging process makes it progressively more difficult to restore their supply . It has been shown that people who have higher levels of oxidative stress are more likely to suffer from a wide range of diseases including cardiovascular disease , arthritis , diabetes and some cancers .

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s , for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical things could not be translated into statements about physical experiences . The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ends by the early 1940s ; this phase was due to be replaced by the reductionist phase , as it became clear that scientific statements about macroscopic and microscopic objects could not be. However , we have seen that the arguments that ended the phenomenalist phase of empiricism and replaced it with the reductionist phase are all circular : they rely for their force on the meaning of concepts in the theory that is supposed to replace the phenomenalist. The first step in the reductionist phase is to find macroscopic concepts that will be used to replace all of the phenomenalist concepts — that is , concepts that will do most of the work in accounting for phenomenalist statements . If that is done , the argument that replaces the phenomenalist theory with the reductionist theory has the form : ( 1 ) The reductionist theory is complete . All truths about the phenomenon are statements that can be deduced by the reductionist theory from the laws of physics and from empirical generalizations about phenomena .

The area of modern Zhejiang was outside the major sphere of influence of the Shang civilization during the second millennium BC . Instead , this area was populated by peoples such as the Wuyun and Jinhu , whose cultures have been excavated at sites such as Chenggang and Yangshao . The cultures of the Wuyun and Jinhu peoples bear little resemblance to Shang culture , and the cultural influence of Shang upon this area was very small . Shang culture was strongest in the southern area of modern Zhejiang , centering on the Zhu River around Pinyin Jiange . Zhejiang is the southernmost of the Five Great Ancient Chinese Dynasties , the northern boundary of the region lying along the southern reaches of the Yangtze River . As the area was an important part of the ancient Silk Road , Zhejiang has a long history of cultural integration with central , eastern , and northern China , as well as the surrounding areas of eastern and southern China . Zhejiang was a major hub of the Song Dynasty , and remains an important area for China 's modern economy .

The Warehouse was owned by The Tribesman aka Jesse Saunders and Larry Sherman . The Warehouse was considered to be a small club with a simple sound system and basic lighting . When asked if `` House music `` is an American music genre , the answer is true . The majority of house music was , and continues to be , made in America , although some UK artists and producers have had a great influence on the genre . The Chicago house scene was more or less born in the home of Frankie Knuckles , a DJ that at the time owned his own house music record label named Trax Records . Soon after the release of Phuture 's ` Acid Tracks ' , DJ 's at other Chicago venues began to seek other records with similar basslines and simple lyrics so a new sub genre named `` The Chicago Sound `` was.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms , the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century . There , economic development was based on the development of urban centres , a system of taxation and local representation . The centre of this ‘ new empire ’ was the capital , Constantinople , and the Greek - speaking people of the empire , who were known as the Vlachs . It was through the activities of the Vlachs that Western European culture found its way across the Mediterranean to Byzantium . 1 . At home , the introduction of Christianity transformed the empire , which was divided between Roman Orthodox and Armenian Christian , with the Byzantine Orthodox the most influential faith . The clergy were supported and educated by the Emperor , while schools were founded to bring learning within the reach of all . 2 . In 612 , the Byzantine Emperor Heraclius ordered a census of his armies in which , of those recorded , seventy per cent were of non-Greek , non-Roman ancestry . Thus the Empire became increasingly diverse , comprising a mixture of Persians , Arabs , Armenians , Georgians , Franks , and Britons 3 .

Non-religious Umayyad mosaic works were mainly floor panels which decorated the palaces of the caliphs and other high-ranking officials . They were closely modeled after the mosaics of the Roman circus at Pompeii , whose style had gained an outstandingly high reputation in the Islamic world at the time . The mosaic pictures on the walls are usually more ornate as those on the floor ; however , the scenes depicted are always scenes of daily life , mostly court life , in the Byzantine fashion . The scenes from hunting and daily life usually include human figures and animals , including depictions of horses , which indicate that the artists were highly skilled in portraying animals . However , the horses show no signs of their use in warfare , nor the camels ; rather these animals are shown as animals which are often depicted in Roman mosaics . Umayyads tended to copy the Roman style faithfully and were not as creative as either the Byzantines or even the Persians . In some of the Umayyad mosaics the scene of two male figures on a couch is accompanied by the Greek letter Chi ( Χ ) ; which was used by Christian and Greek writers as the abbreviation for Christ ( ,.

By August 1805 , Napoleon had realized that the strategic situation had changed fundamentally . Facing a potential invasion from his continental enemies , he decided to strike first and decisively . In a major act of pre-emptive self-defense , he sent a series of detachments of 5,000 soldiers and 1,500 horsemen down the coast into Spain . The objective of the troops , under Marshal Michel Ney , was to capture the strategically important port city of Cádiz on the east coast of Spain and to occupy it as a base from which to attack England . The campaign to occupy Cádiz and then to besiege it during the summer of 1805 thus began as a major expeditionary raid against Spain . The strategy of Napoleonic France in 1805 was an attempt to avoid a two - front war . Rather than face war with everyone in Europe simultaneously , Napoleon sought to use the campaign against Cádiz and Spain in general in order to deal with one major enemy at the present time while preparing to engage others . It was a strategy of `` limited war , '' to use a modern expression , against Spain at the behest of revolutionary and radical Spain .

The Defence Committee—Third Report `` Defence Equipment 2009 '' cites an article from the Financial Times website stating that the Chief of Defence Materiel , General Sir Kevin O ’ Connor , has said that there is a `` 'redundancy ' of more than 30 % of the British Army 's current equipment ( of which the infantry battalions comprise about 50 % ) . The problem has been caused by defence budget cuts initiated by the United Kingdom before the election of the Conservative Party in 1997 with a view to reducing the military strength . However , more recent spending proposes that the army will not be reduced below 102,000 personnel as early as 2017 — a figure that is to be reached in just 82 % of the time. It is thus unsurprising that there are many gaps in the equipment that are required to be fielded before that year . The Defence Committee concludes from this that the Department of Defence can not fulfil its obligation to the Army to equip it adequately—not least in view of the fact that the army is expected to be at only 50 % strength by 2016 . This is an important issue , insofar as it affects all British soldiers , but it is particularly critical for infantry soldiers in the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers .

On 29 November 1947 , the United Nations General Assembly recommended the adoption and implementation of the Partition Plan for Mandatory Palestine . This UN plan specified borders for new Arab and Jewish states in Palestine and provided for special arrangements for the City of Jerusalem and its surrounds as an internationalised enclave . Israel approved the creation of an Palestinian state in 1947 yet Palestinian forces rejected the UN partition plan and were unwilling to make compromises with Israel . However , when it became clear that Israel was prepared to declare indepenedence , Palestine forces launched their defence of Palestine and initiated the 1948 Arab-Israeli War to protect their homeland . Israel was ready for this war to the Arab-Israeli war , and so were able to quickly overtake the surrounding Arab nations . During the war about 100,000 Palestinians died while about 60,000 were displaced . Around 530 cities and towns that belonged to Palestinians were destroyed while 120 Palestinians towns were destroyed . Moreover , in an ongoing effort to take control of the Palestinian territories and ensure peace in the region Israel also launched a “ population transfer ” of about 450,000 Arabs from the Arab states to a newly established state known as Jordan . The Palestinian refugee crisis : this led to a large population of Palestinians outside Palestine ( in which Palestinian refugees living in Gaza Strip or in Lebanon ) and the refugee were without citizenship in any state .

In response to attribution of recent climate change , the City of Melbourne , in 2002 , set a target to reduce carbon emissions to net zero by 2020 and establish a target for carbon offset projects . The City began funding projects in 2008 and has now reached more than $ 15 million in offset investments and is approaching the target of $ 20 million . Melbourne is already a leader in the development and commercialisation of carbon offset projects within Australia , and has successfully developed the `` Forest Stewardship Standard for Carbon Farming '' in conjunction with the Victorian Department of Environment and Primary Industries . This project aims to create a forest management standard that recognises the complex challenges of managing forests for ecological outcomes as well as carbon , and will enable the City to purchase the services of managing carbon farms . While the carbon credits generated from some projects are purchased to assist with achieving the annual carbon offset target , offsets purchased from other projects would not be used to meet targets but would be retained in the portfolio to assist with funding future offset activities . Initially , Burke did not condemn the French Revolution . In a letter of 9 August 1789 , Burke wrote : `` England gazing with astonishment at a French struggle between liberty and despotism , can only rejoice . `` After the Revolution , however , he expressed concern about the consequences of the revolutionary violence in France . He said : `` A Frenchman is not a Frenchman while he doth rebel against the French . `` When King Louis XVI was executed , Burke stated that he was horrified , but he explained that the king 'would have committed even worse crimes if he 'd not been put to death . Burke did not accept the popular belief during his lifetime that the French Revolution was a good thing . Burke saw the French Revolution as a threat to civilization . In his Reflections , Burke wrote that he didn 't understand what good would come from the destruction of France . His criticism of the French Revolution was based on a belief that people who don 't know or appreciate their history will be unsuccessful . The problem with the revolution was that it did not fully understand the rights of men nor understand its own history .

In a number of countries , although being today generally considered similar institutions of higher learning across many countries , polytechnics and institutes of technology used to have a quite different role . The former used to be seen as low status institutions and their courses as less academic in nature than what could be found at universities . This did not mean though that they were exclusively involved in vocational education and training . Around the world many polytechnics were quite selective in terms of applicants . To have access to this type of institution students often had to gain a high school diploma . In more recent years , however , this stereotype that polytechnics / institutes of technology are associated with vocational education and training rather than with academic learning has been challenged . The academic standing of the institutions has risen and many students attend those institutions that had been regarded in the past as low status institutions in the field of higher education . Some institutions that originally had the status of polytechnics or institutes of technology have evolved into universities with a changed focus from having a vocational and technical orientation into developing a more all-round education and training at university level ..

New York served as the capital of the United Provinces of America for six months and the capital of the United States from 1785 until 1790 . Different phases of digestion take place including : the cephalic phase , gastric phase , and intestinal phase . The cephalic phase occurs at the sight , thought and smell of food while the gastric phase occurs as the food is chewed and mixed with saliva to form bolus . Also known as the gastric secretion phase , food stimulates the secretion of HCl to activate pepsin to allow the gastric phase to take place . This results the secretion of gastric juice and digestive enzymes in the stomach . After , the intestinal phase completes in the small intestine using enzymes . In the spring of 1800 , Napoleon and his troops crossed the Swiss Alps into Italy , aiming to surprise the Austrian armies that had reoccupied the peninsula when Napoleon left it in 1799 to march against the Ottoman Turks on the eastern front . Upon reaching Mantua , near the Austrian frontier , Napoleon paused to regroup his forces . He intended to cross the Alps again in the autumn of that year to confront the Russian armies of Count Alexander Suverov and the Austrian armies of the Archduchess Maria Louise , which would have assembled on the east bank of. the Danube , preparing to attack France , but before marching to the other side of the Alps , he had to dispose of the Austrians in Italy . This involved three battles that eventually included about 150,000 soldiers ; the largest concentration of troops Napoleon had gathered in Italy up to that time . The first battle was that of Marengo , fought on 14 June 1800 . This short and bloodless clash between 5,700 French infantry and 16,000 Austrians left the French in control of the high plains around Genoa and Ventimiglia .

In biology , energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism . Within an organism it is responsible for growth and development , as well as for maintaining life functions such as reproduction , thermoregulation and movement . The energy for all these processes is absorbed from the environment primarily as a result of photosynthesis in plants . Energy is also a measure of work . An energy level is the set of states of a quantum mechanical system that corresponds to a particular value of an energy . The state of a quantum mechanical system is described by a wave function , which is the solution of the Schrödinger equation . # # Classical versus quantum biology Classical biology is based on the premise that the macroscopic world and its phenomena consist of things that are always either whole or complete , and can never be disassembled into. more fundamental units . Quantum biology , on the other hand , is based on the premise that microscopic phenomena , like atoms and electrons , possess discrete energies . The idea is that life emerges only under conditions of low entropy .

The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school reading from high school to college . Virgil followed the epic conventions of Homer and the Greeks that included a prologue , a lengthy invocation of the Muses , a hero , the invocation of gods , supernatural intervention , and death of those characters who were unfaithful to their gods . The Aeneid , particularly , begins in medias res rather than beginning at the birth of its hero , as did Homer ’ s epics . Although Virgil is considered the founder of Latin poetry , he did follow the poets that came before him , and used the meter of Horace and Lucretius . In the Aeneid Virgil made extensive use of the epic poetry of Homer and other poets of the era . The Aeneid is a historical epic poem , not a true history , written about , but tells the story of , a hero in ancient Rome . The poems begin in 509 B.

By 1959 , American observers believed that the Soviet Union would be the first to get a human into space , because of the time needed to prepare for Mercury flight 15 , and the launch of P. E. Tcherepanov as a cosmonaut as part of a high altitude balloon experiment the previous year . The United States then prepared to launch Pioneer , its own program of unmanned craft to explore the Solar System . Project Pioneer succeeded and in April 1958 began launching satellites into near - Earth orbit . By December 1958 , an orbital network covering the United States , the USSR and the European continent was established in orbit . The network was known as the Transit Network . The Pioneer series consisted of 11 spacecraft launched from 1958 to 1962 . These became the first American spacecraft to travel to the Moon in the absence of a human . In the Soviet Union , the Vostok program was launched in late 1958 to compete with Mercury , and by March 1960 , the first Sputnik 1 satellite was launched . The Vostok program successfully sent Yuri Gagarin into space on April 12 , 1961 , on the same day that Mercury flight 15 was canceled by the USSR because there were no trained pilots left on standby by that time.

The island of Saint Helena has a total area of 122 km2 ( 47 sq mi ) , and is composed largely of rugged terrain of volcanic origin ( the largest volcano is Pyramid Hill , which is 553 m high ) and forest . The northern coastline of the island is rugged and deeply indented . The western coast of the island consists of high vertical limestone cliffs ; whereas , the eastern coast is composed mostly of small sandy beaches , small bays , and rocks . The island ’ s interior features low hills and uplands . The highest point on the island is 1,400 m ( 4,623 ft ) above sea level at Sand Pond Hill . The highest mountain is the , which is 2,035 m ( 6,737 ft ) tall . The island is surrounded by sea water of variable depth . The island is composed entirely of volcanic rock . Apart from the central mountain massif and the two volcanic cones Mounts Diana and Prince Andrew , there are no mountain ranges on the island . Some parts of the interior of the island can only be accessed by a few footpaths .

This is not a metaphysical question ; it is a question of the laws of nature . The Canadian football field is 150 yards ( 137 m ) long and 65 yards ( 59 m ) wide with end zones 20 yards ( 18 m ) deep at each end . The team with the ball is in the offense and the opposing team is in defense — called offensive line and defensive line . Canada football is a game 12 players per side on offense and defense . The offense tries to move the ball down the field as far as they can by running or passing the ball to another player until reaching the other end of the field . The offense has four opportunities to move the ball ten yards or more . If after completing these four attempts they are still successful they get to move the ball four more times and repeat the process until they score or turn over the ball . The clock starts when the offense snaps , and ends when the ball gets in or out of bounds or is kicked by the defense . For each game , eight Canadian football teams play four regular season games and four playoff games .

The deliberate or accidental hybridising of two or more species of closely related animals through captive breeding is a human activity which has been in existence for millennia and has undoubtedly enriched the experience of countless thousands of the species ' followers . There are few examples where hybridising has been considered a threat or a serious risk – in fact it has been accepted that it is often a natural part of the reproduction process . The potential benefits of cross - breeding have also been recognised by the authorities on occasion , for instance the deliberate attempts to preserve and develop species such as the Bengal Tiger or the Indian Elephant . In other cases there have been unintended results , one of which has been to increase the size of a ' target ' species from smaller to larger examples . This may be considered an asset or a problem , depending on one ' s point of view , but there have been no complaints that such hybridising should be classified as something which is intrinsically harmful to animal welfare . In general however we can state with considerable confidence that the majority of successful species -hybridisations represent entirely positive benefits to the welfare of those animals and also to the humans who have a vested interest in them , as indeed all those situations arise where.

Switzerland lies between latitudes 45° and 48° N , and longitudes 5° and 11° E. It contains three basic topographical areas : the Swiss Alps to the south , the Swiss Plateau to the center and north , and the Swiss Neck to the north . The main rivers are the Rhine , Rhone , and Lake Geneva ( Lac Leman ) . The northern Swiss Plateau extends to about 6,280 feet ( 1,870 m ) between latitudes 46. 8 ° and 47 ° 45 ' N . This area is about 40– 106 miles ( 65 – 170 km ) wide . The Alps , situated over the southern Swiss Plateau , are formed by the Jura Mountains to the west and the southern foothills of the Pennines to the northeast . The Swiss Alps extend southward from the canton of Ticino ( the Italian - speaking territory in southwestern Switzerland ) to almost 3,100 feet ( 0 . 914 m ) above sea level and border Germany , France , Italy and Liechtenstein . Switzerland has no major rivers that rise in the Alps .

As Muslim institutions of higher learning , the madrasa had the legal designation of waqf . In central and eastern Islamic lands , the view that the madrasa , as a place of religious instruction , should be separate from secular learning gradually emerged . Madrasa education was a means of acquiring higher learning and knowledge , not a primary education . The education that was imparted at the madrasa was intended to help students acquire religious knowledge , and was not an attempt to build rational thinkers or people of science and discovery . Many Islamic scholars during the medieval period felt that the madrasa was also meant to serve as a vehicle for the propagation of Islam throughout the world . The word madrasa can refer to the institution as well as to its student body , where the word was commonly used in the 16th century to describe students that either resided at a mosque , or were attached to it . A student at a madrasa was sometimes known as a muḥṣib ( literally , `` one who is concerned with religious studies `` ) , and in order to differentiate from other forms of higher education , they were also referred to as madrasa mu. The Madrasa would also send its students out in the community to preach , known as khatmiyya , literally `` spread out `` .
